conclusion: Radar emits radio waves and detects reflections to find distance.
Radar works by measuring time delay of waves bouncing back.
Radar emits pulses lasting 1 μs with 100 μs intervals.
Speed of light is c = 3.0 × 10^8 m/s.
Figure shows sharp waves on indicator's screen with ab = bc.
Time difference between transmitted and received pulses is round-trip time.
Distance to obstacle is (c * (T_rx - T_tx)) / 2.
Figure likely shows time-based display with peaks for emitted and received signals.
Assume a, b, c are time axis markings for pulses.
Assume point a is transmission of first pulse, b is reception of echo, c is transmission of second pulse.
ab = bc implies T_b - T_a = T_c - T_b.
Denote T_b - T_a = T_c - T_b = t.
Round-trip time for first pulse is T_b - T_a = t.
Distance to obstacle is (c * t) / 2.
Interval between emissions is 100 μs.
T_c = T_a + 2t and T_c - T_a = 100 μs.
2t = 100 μs implies t = 50 μs.
Round-trip time is 50 μs.
Final distance is 15,000 m / 2.
